title: MG: The Power of Preparedness

content: Picture this: You’re home alone and you suddenly feel a flare creeping in. Or you’re rushed to a hospital where the staff isn’t familiar with myasthenia gravis (MG). Living with MG means these scenarios aren’t just “what-ifs” — they’re real possibilities that can disrupt your life in an instant.

For someone like me, whose condition requires daily management and constant vigilance, being unprepared isn’t an option. Over the years, I’ve learned that while you can’t predict emergencies, you can plan for them. And that preparation makes all the difference.

Oddly enough, my dedication to being prepared was sparked after watching the movie A Quiet Place: Day One . Without giving too much away, there’s a scene where the main character, who has cancer, realizes mid-apocalypse she doesn’t have enough medication. While I was sitting there in the cinema, I thought: “What if something unexpected happened and I didn’t have the medication I rely on?”

content: Before this, I was the type of person who packed exactly what I needed and no more. If I was going away for three days, I’d bring three days’ worth of pills. After watching that film, I realized how risky that approach is. I vowed to always carry way more than I thought I’d need.
Because while alien invasions are unlikely, lost luggage, delayed travel, or just forgetting something at home are inevitable scenarios.
The foundation of my emergency plan starts with truly knowing my MG.

Understanding my triggers – whether stress, overheating, or overexertion – helps me stay one step ahead. But even with the best management, emergencies can strike out of nowhere. That’s why I’ve trained myself to spot the early warning signs: a sudden dip in muscle strength, difficulty swallowing, or changes in my breathing. Recognizing these symptoms quickly is key to taking action before things escalate.
Preparation isn’t just about awareness, it’s also about having the right tools at hand.

I’ve created my “MG emergency kit,” a lifesaver in any crisis. I keep an ample supply of medications, with at least two weeks’ worth of pyridostigmine and steroids. A small but crucial addition is a card that details my condition, medications, and my neurologist’s contact information. This card is always in my wallet, ensuring that if I’m unable to communicate, my essentials are clear for anyone who needs them.

content: My phone is also a critical part of my plan. It’s loaded with emergency contacts, including my neurologist, primary care doctor, and trusted family members who understand my MG. And because my phone is so vital, I carry a portable charger everywhere to ensure it’s never out of battery when I need it most.
Of course, carrying this kit everywhere means some sacrifices — like upgrading my handbags. Forget dainty clutches. I’ve embraced oversized bags that hold my emergency kit and my makeup.
It’s all about balancing practicality and staying true to myself.

There are a few other essentials I always keep with me. I never leave the house without water or some type of liquid. MG can cause swallowing difficulties, and having something to sip helps me clear my throat and take my pills safely when needed. This simple habit has saved me countless times.
Another must-have is my radar key, which gives me access to disabled toilets wherever I go. It’s a small tool that ensures I have a private space when fatigue or symptoms strike unexpectedly.

content: For situations where I need to leave home suddenly, I organized my medications and supplies in a portable container. This makes it easy to grab everything I need if I have to go to the hospital or evacuate due to an unforeseen event.

Since heat tends to worsen my symptoms, I prepared cooling spray and portable fans to help manage moments when environmental conditions add to my physical challenges. On the flip side, since cold weather can also make things tricky, I carry hand warmers and a fleece with built-in body warmers. These small but thoughtful preparations give me confidence that I can adapt no matter the situation.

A big part of my preparation involves communicating with those around me. I’ve made sure my family and close friends understand what MG is and how it affects me. They know what to do if I’m in distress, which is an incredible relief during moments when I might not be able to advocate for myself. I’ve also found that emergency apps are a great tool for storing my medical information, ensuring that first responders can access it instantly if needed.

content: Emergencies are inherently stressful, and stress is one of the worst triggers for MG symptoms. That’s why I focus on mental preparation as much as physical readiness.

Practicing mindfulness and grounding techniques has become part of my routine. These tools help me stay calm when the unexpected happens, giving me the mental clarity to act effectively when every second counts.
At the heart of all this preparation is one simple truth: Planning ahead gives me control over what could otherwise feel like chaos.

Knowing I’ve done everything I can to protect myself allows me to face emergencies with a sense of calm and confidence. While MG adds complexity to life, it’s taught me the strength and resilience needed to handle anything that comes my way.
Emergencies may be inevitable, but they don’t have to derail you. With the right tools, mindset, and support, you can face them head-on.
